CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;No violation of P1-1;No violation of Art. 14+P1-1;No violation of Art. 9
JUDGES: Ganna Yudkivska;Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .

CARDINAL . Under the NORP Federal Hunting Law ( Bundesjagdgesetz ) , owners of hunting grounds with a surface of CARDINAL hectares are de jure members of a hunting association ( ORG ) , while owners of bigger plots of land manage their own hunting district . The applicant owns CARDINAL landholdings in GPE - Palatinate which are smaller than QUANTITY in a single block . He is thus an automatic member of a hunting association , in the instant case of the municipality of GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant , who is opposed to hunting on ethical grounds , filed a request with the hunting authority to terminate his adherence to the hunting association . The authority rejected his request on the grounds that his adherence was prescribed by law and that there was no provision on the termination of adherence .

CARDINAL . The applicant brought proceedings before ORG . Relying in particular on the ORG 's judgment in the case of PERSON and Others v. GPE ( [ ORG ] nos . ORG , CARDINAL and CARDINAL , ECHR CARDINALIII ) , he requested the court to establish that he was not a member of the hunting association of the municipality of Langsur .

CARDINAL . On DATE the administrative court rejected the applicant 's request . It considered that ORG law did not violate the applicant 's rights . With regard to the PERSON - judgment the administrative court considered that the situation in GPE differed from the one in GPE . It observed , in particular , that the NORP owners of hunting grounds , by way of their adherence to the hunting association , were in a position to influence the decision - making process on how the hunting rights should be exercised . Furthermore , they had a right to receive a share of the profits derived from the exploitation of the hunting rights . All owners of plots which were too small to allow a proper management of hunting rights adhered to a hunting association . The court also considered that the hunting associations did not only serve the leisure interests of those who exercised the hunting rights , but imposed certain specific obligations on them , which served the general interest , in particular the duty to manage the game stock with the aim of maintaining varied and healthy game populations and to avoid damages caused by wild game . They were furthermore obliged to comply with specific quotas set by the administration for the hunting of game . These duties applied in the same way to the owners of hunting grounds more the CARDINAL hectares of area , notwithstanding the fact that these bigger plots were not regrouped in hunting associations .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the Rhineland - Palatinate Administrative Court of Appeal and ORG rejected the applicant 's appeals on the same grounds as the administrative court .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG ( CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) refused to admit the applicant 's constitutional complaint for adjudication . It noted , at the outset , that the provisions of LAW did not violate the applicant 's right to the peaceful enjoyment of his property , but defined and limited the exercise of this right in a proportionate way . The relevant provisions pursued legitimate aims , were necessary and did not impose an excessive burden on the landowners .

CARDINAL . When defining the content and the limits of property rights , the legislator had to weigh the proprietors ' legitimate interests against the general interest . He had , in particular , to respect the principles of proportionality and of equal treatment . The limitations imposed on the exercise of property rights must not infringe the core area of the protected right . The margin of appreciation allocated to the legislator depended on the specific context ; the stronger the social context , the wider the margin of appreciation .

CARDINAL . Applying these principles to the instant case , ORG considered that the applicant 's obligatory adherence to a hunting association did not violate his property rights . The core - area of that right was not infringed . LAW pursued legitimate aims and limited the property rights in a proportionate way . Encompassed in the notion of “ management and protection of the game stock ( PERSON ) ” , it had the aim to preserve the game in a way that was adapted to the rural and cultural conditions , and to ensure a healthy and varied wildlife . Under LAW , game keeping was not only an instrument to prevent damages caused by wild - life , but also to avoid any impediment to the agricultural , forestry and fishery exploitation of the land . These aims served the general interest .

CARDINAL . The obligatory adherence to a hunting association was an appropriate and necessary means to achieve these aims . Referring to paragraph CARDINAL of the above - cited PERSON judgment , ORG considered that the ORG had acknowledged that it was undoubtedly in the general interest to avoid unregulated hunting and encourage the rational management of game stocks . The obligatory adherence to a hunting association was also a proportionate means . The impact on the property rights was not particularly serious and did not outweigh the general interest in a rational management of game stocks . Furthermore , LAW endowed every member with the right to participate in the decisionmaking process and to receive a share of the profits derived from the lease of the hunting rights .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court further considered that there was no violation of the applicant 's freedom of conscience . Referring to paragraph CARDINAL of the PERSON judgment , it accepted that the applicant 's convictions attained a certain level of cogency , cohesion and importance and where therefore worthy of respect in a NORP society . Accordingly , ORG considered that the applicant 's complaint might fall within the scope of freedom of conscience , but that there was , in any event , no violation of that right . The applicant was neither enjoined to exercise the hunt himself , nor to participate in it or to support it . The fact that he had to tolerate the exercise of the hunt on his premises did not result from his own decision , but was the result of the legislator 's legitimate decision . The right to freedom of conscience did not encompass the right that the whole legal order was submitted to one 's own ethical standards . If the legal order distributed the right to exploit a certain property to several claimholders , the owner 's conscience did not necessarily outweigh the other claimholders ' constitutional rights . If the applicant 's landholding – and that of other owners who were opposed to hunting DATE were removed from the hunting association because of their convictions , the whole system of property ownership and of the management of the game stock would be jeopardised . The right to freedom of conscience did not outweigh the general interest in the instant case .

CARDINAL . The Federal Constitutional Court further considered that the applicant 's complaint did not come within the scope of the right to freedom of association , because the NORP hunting associations were of a public nature . Vested with administrative , rule - making and disciplinary prerogatives , they remained integrated into ORG structures . There was thus no doubt that the association was not simply qualified as “ public ” in order to remove it from the scope of LAW .

CARDINAL . The Federal Constitutional Court further considered that the applicant 's right to equal treatment had not been violated . There was an objective reason which justified drawing a distinction between the owners of landholdings QUANTITY in area and those CARDINAL hectares in area . Contrary to the situation in GPE , which had been examined by ORG in the PERSON judgment , ORG applied to the whole surface of GPE and was binding on all landowners . The owners of land QUANTITY in area had the same duties in game keeping as those adhering to hunting associations .

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG observed that the administrative courts had considered the PERSON judgment and had accentuated the differences between the NORP law and LAW as applicable at the relevant time .
CARDINAL . Article QUANTITY of LAW provides :

“ Mindful also of its responsibility toward future generations , the ORG shall protect the natural bases of life by legislation and , in accordance with law and justice , by executive and judicial action , all within the framework of the constitutional order . ”

Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL of LAW ( Bundesjagdgesetz ) provides that the hunting right encompasses the right to manage and protect the game stock on a particular area of land , to exercise the hunt and to take possession of the game . The hunting right is linked to the duty to manage and protect the game stock ( PERSON ) .

Under LAW of that section , the management of the game stock is aimed at maintaining varied and healthy game populations at level compatible with land care and cultural conditions and at avoiding game damage .

§ CARDINAL distinguishes between the hunting right ( PERSON ) and the right to exercise the hunt ( ORG des Jagdrechts ) . The landowner has the hunting right on his LOC . The right to exercise the hunt is regulated by the following provisions :
Section CARDINAL of the Hunting PERSON provides :
“ The hunt may be exercised either on private hunting districts ( section CARDINAL ) or common hunting districts ( section CARDINAL) . ”
Section CARDINAL ( enclosed LOC , stay of the hunt ) reads as follows :

“ The hunt is stayed on surfaces , which do not belong to a hunting district , and on enclosed surfaces ( befriedete ORG ) . A limited exercise of the hunt may be permitted . This law does not apply to zoological gardens . ”

Section CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that plots of QUANTITY of surface which can be exploited on an agricultural , forestry or fishery level and which belong to CARDINAL single owner constitute a private hunting district .
Section CARDINAL provides that all surfaces which do not belong to a private hunting district constitute a common hunting district if they have an overall surface of QUANTITY .
Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides as follows :
“ The owners of surfaces belonging to a common hunting district form a hunting association . Owners of surfaces on which the hunt must not be exercised do not belong to the hunting association . ”
Section CARDINAL reads as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) The hunting association generally exploits the hunt by lease - hold . The lease can be limited to the members of the association ( ... )

( CARDINAL ) The hunting association is allowed to practice the hunt on its own account by chartered hunters . With the agreement of the competent authority , it can decide to stay the hunt ( Ruhen der Jagd ) .

( CARDINAL ) The association decides about the use of the net profit of the hunt . If the association decides not to distribute it to the owners of hunting grounds according to the surface they own , each owner who had contested this decision is allowed to claim his share . ... ”
Section CARDINAL provides :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Hunting is prohibited in areas where the practice of the hunt would , under the specific circumstances of the case , disturb public peace , order or security or would endanger human life .
( CARDINAL ) The practice of the hunt in nature and wildlife protection areas and in national and wildlife parks is regulated by the Länder . ”
Section CARDINAL provides :

“ ( CARDINAL ) The shooting of the game is to be regulated in a way which fully safeguards the legitimate interests of agriculture , fishery and forestry to be protected from damages caused by wild game and which takes into account the necessities of nature protection and landscape conservation . Within these limits , the regulation of the shooting of the game shall contribute to maintain a healthy population of all domestic game in adequate numbers and , in particular , ensure the protection of endangered species . ”
Section CARDINAL of the Hunting Law of the Land of Rhineland - Palatinate provides , inter alia , as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) ORG is a public law corporation . It is subject to ORG supervision . The supervision is exercised by the lower hunting authority ... The hunting association has to issue its own internal statute ( ORG ) . The internal statute has to be approved by the supervising authority unless it is in accordance with a model statute issued by the highest hunting authority ; in this case notice of the statute has to be given to the lower hunting authority . If the hunting association fails to issue a statute within DATE after the issue of the model statute , the supervising authority issues an internal statute and publishes it ... at the expense of the association .

( CARDINAL ) Cost orders ( ORG ) are to be executed under the provisions of the law on the execution of administrative acts . The execution rights are exercised by the exchequer who executes the claims of the community in which the association is situated .... ”
